reviewText: Not quite noir, but not a pure caper either, this film cooks along at a blistering pace, and gets by on a great script, assured direction from Don (Dirty Harry) Siegel, and effortless charm.Actually it does a lot more than get by. The dialogue is first-rate, the performances are fine, the locations authentic. And the momentum never ebbs. I liken the pace to a pre-code Warner Bros. meller.It begins with William Bendix kicking in Robert Mitchum's door, looking for Army payroll he believes Mitchum stole. Mitchum denies it and they fight. Mitchum escapes the boat he had been travelling on and meets Jane Greer on the Mexican dock. The next few minutes mess with the audience's mind, as more characters are introduced: who did steal the money? Why? Where is it? Where are they trying to go with it?Once the shifting alliances become set, it actually gets better. The narrative is more straightforward, but remains actionful and clever, an endless cat-and-mouse game between Mitchum and Greer, who are chasing Greer's wily ex-fiancee; Bendix, who is chasing them; with a Mexican policeman who is more savvy than he lets on is pursuing all of them.There are a couple very nice vignettes which never make the movie seem episodic, including a three-sided battle of wits by a hotel swimming pool and a comical encounter with a Mexican road crew. There's a couple of shootouts, a nice car chase, some goats, more fisticuffs, a final batch of betrayals, and a romantic fadeout. Heist films could end happy in the black-and-white days, you see, and the good guys could win.Later films may have become even more twisty, but they cannot match the entertainment value of this one from 1949.The Big Steal reunites Mitchum, Greer and co-scripter Geoffrey Homes from 1947's Out of the Past, although the two offerings are completely different in tone. This one is basically light fare with a dose of hard-boiled; O of P was pure gloom. And overall, this is definitely a notch down from that classic. (Big Steal would have benefited from an antagonist of more presence, such as Kirk Douglas in O of P, in the role of Greer's fiancee.) But being a step below Tourneur's noir masterpiece still leaves it in very good stead indeed.Buy the Big Steal- you won't be sorry.P.S. Who owns the rights to all the RKO gems? And when will we see them released on DVD?
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Stop calling me Chiquita. You don't say that to girls you don't even know." -- Jane Greer"You do where I learned Spanish." -- MitchumDon Siegel's wonderful crime caper is one long and happy fiesta for the viewer, with Mitchum and Greer finding romance while chasing and being chased all over Mexico for a stolen Army payroll everyone wants for different reasons. Shot on location for the most part, the laid-back atmosphere of Mexico seems tailor-made for Mitchum's personality, while adding a spicy flavor to a story which moves faster than a speeding bullet. Jane Greer had been a big hit opposite Mitchum in Out of the Past and slid sideways into The Big Steal when Lizabeth Scott dropped out so close to shooting that RKO owner Howard Hughes allowed her to recapture their magic. While the former pairing of the two is a noir classic, this one has a lighter tone, making it more fun to watch. It also boasts a terrific performance from silent star Ramon Navarro as the sly cop letting all the American mice play with their ball of yarn while he waits to see what they unravel.It gets underway with a bang, Duke Halliday (Robert Mitchum) escaping the clutches of Captain Blake (William Bendix) on a ship docked in Mexico and assuming his identity. He runs into Joan Graham (Jane Greer) once he's stepped off the gangplank and shortly realizes she's after Fiske (Patrick Knowles), who just happens to be the same guy he's after. Halliday shadows her until they finally hook up for the chase with a map she's stolen from her former beau to guide them. A very upset Blake is hot on their tail, however. When Halliday passes himself off to Inspector Ortega (Ramon Navarro) as Captain Blake and gives him a sketchy story containing just enough facts to be plausible, the wily Ortega lets them go to see where it all leads. He has more mice to play with when the real Blake shows up and tells a similar tale, only turned around. Unbeknownst to all the Americans chasing each other, Ortega is also chasing someone, using the gringos to bait the mouse he wants. You have Halliday and Joan chasing Fiske, Blake chasing them, and Ortega keeping an eye on them all like a cheshire cat.If all this sounds like great fun, that's because it is. Mexico locations and a winning cast offer a marvelous time at the movies, with a twist near the end you won't see coming. Halliday has to constantly have Chiquita translate because his Spanish was learned in places not frequented by ladies! When the principals all end up together, a wild melee leads to a delightful ending as Mitchum and Greer watch children from a wedding party pass by with the obvious implication it is a look at their future. Describing this film as one long chase sequence across Mexico simply does not do it justice. The Big Steal and Macao are my two favorite Mitchum films, and once you have seen them, you'll know why. Richard Wormser's story, The Road to Carmichael's, was adapted by Geoffrey Homes and Gerald Drayson Adams and there isn't a wasted moment to found anywhere. There is a great amount of fun to be derived from viewings of The Big Steal, one of the stellar films in the Mitchum canon. Available on DVD as part of a boxed set, this entertaining film can also be viewed on VHS for those interested in this particular film alone. Those who loved Mitchum and Greer in Out of the Past but hated the outcome, will find the breezy Spanish atmosphere and action laced with humor more to their liking. The ending here is much more the stuff of which dreams are made. Great fun!
summary: A Breezy Chase Film Loaded With Fun
Title: N/A

reviewText: Robert Mitchum plays Army Lt. Duke Halliday who has arrived by ship to Veracruz in pursuit of Patric Knowles playing Jim Fiske.  Mitchum a financial officer is chasing Knowles who absconded with $300,000 in U.S. Army payroll.  Mitchum himself is being trailed by his superior Capt. Vincent Blake played by William Bendix who is convinced that Mitchum is in cahoots with Knowles.Aboard the ship Mitchum had a casual meeting with Jane Greer playing Joan Graham but she gives him the brush off.  Mitchum is surprised that when discovering the whereabouts of Knowles in a Veracruz hotel, he arrives there to find that he's fled and Greer is in his room showering.  It turns out that she's his jilted fiancee and that he's also stolen $2000 from her.  They team up to go after him after discovering that he's headed to a small town outside of Tehuacan.Using some excellent cinematography of the Mexican countryside the team of Greer and Mitchum are hot on the tail of Knowles in a frenetic chase. At the same time they're being pursued by Bendix.  To complicate matters further Mexican Police Inspector General Ortega played by Ramon Novarro is observing and also following all the players in this drama.They eventually snake their way through meandering and treacherous mountain roads and small villages admixed with occasional gun battles along the way.  Knowles' final destination is the lair of a fence who will trade the stolen payroll funds for some laundered currency.  The finale of the film reveals an unexpected series of twists that enhance the storyline.The Don Siegel directed "The Big Steal" is a decent melodramatic film noir that features the droopy eyed Mitchum as a classic anti-hero whose casual and laconic manner belies his torrid screen presence.
Title: N/A

reviewText: One of the great stars of the 1940's, 50's and 60's was Robert Mitchum.  His name is still fairly well known but he remains a star a notch below the big names of his era.  Part of that is due to his tendency to make pictures that either didn't challenge his talent or allow it to really surface.  I'm a big fan of his but I've wasted many a 90 minute time slot watching mediocre movies he starred in.  I keep watching because when he's good, he's very good.  I'm happy to add "The Big Steal" to the list of his better preformances.  This is a movie that starts out with action, has plenty of mystery, romance, and a lot of intrigue.  It helps that we aren't sure who the good guys and the bad guys are.  The developing relationship between Mitchum and the able Jane Greer is well done.  Some of their chatter while traveling is rather surprizing for a movie made in 1949.  The Mexican characters that weave in and out of the movie are well-presented as well for a movie of that time.  There may be an occassional reference to a middle-aged man as "boy" but these guys are smart, interesting, humorous (on a respectable level) and an essential part of the flavor of the movie.  My Spanish gets rusty in North Dakota so I enjoy being able to watch a movie where it is a meaningful part of the dialogue.  The movie maintains its' intrigue through to the end and leaves with a smile on our face.Mitchum excels when he can be the quiet tough guy that starts nothing but finishes everything.  He is great at wisecrcking comebacks and he's got enough of whatever it takes to play the romantic lead.  When he got a decent picture, he was worth the price of admission.  Watch "The Big Steal" and get an idea of why he was one of the best.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a review for THE BIG STEAL (1949) dby Don Siegal. Robert Mitchum plays Army Lt. Duke Halliday in THE BIG STEAL, a film where Halliday is chasing an accused thief, Jim Fiske, played by Patric Knowles, and therefore winds up being pursued by Army brass, Capt. Vincent Blake, played by William Bendix,who believes he is suspicious, across Mexico. Lt.Duke Halliday's ex girlfriend, Joan Graham, played by Jane Greer,is also along for the chase.Fast paced adventure romance with some humor and noirish touches thrown in for good measure.In some ways THE BIG STEAL reunites the OUT OF THE PAST team, Mitchum, Greer and writer Daniel Mainwearing as  Geoffry Homes but THE BIG STEAL is a vastly different type of film.Mitchum, Greer and Bendix seem to be at the top of their games in this one and director Don Siegal, in an early effort, already seemed to be up to the occasion.Four Stars.
Title: N/A
